name: Moretum (Roman Herb and Cheese Spread)
ingredients: 1/2 cup Fresh Rue (or sub with mint)
instructions: In a mortar, crush garlic with sea salt into a paste.
Add fresh herbs (coriander, parsley, rue) and pound until broken down.
Add cheese in chunks and continue pounding.
Mix in white wine vinegar and olive oil.
Stir in pine nuts for texture.
Pound until mixture reaches a spreadable consistency.
Traditionally eaten with spelt bread or flatbread.
Serve as a breakfast spread or appetizer.
history: Moretum is vividly described in the Virgil Appendix as the breakfast of a Roman farmer. The poem details how a peasant named Simulus prepares this cheese and herb spread before his day's work. It represents the simple, rustic diet of common Romans and was typically spread on bread as a morning meal.

name: Parthian Chicken (Pullum Parthicum)
instructions: Season chicken pieces with salt, pepper, and cumin.
Brown chicken in olive oil in a clay pot or heavy pan.
Remove chicken and in same pot, toast pine nuts.
Add dates, fish sauce, wine, honey, and asafoetida.
Return chicken to pot, bring to simmer.
Cover and braise for 45 minutes until tender.
Add lovage or celery leaves in last 5 minutes.
Serve with sauce poured over chicken.
history: This recipe comes from Apicius' 'De Re Coquinaria' (1st century AD) and reflects Rome's trade connections with the Parthian Empire (modern Iran). The sweet-savory combination with dates and cumin shows Eastern influence on Roman aristocratic cuisine. It was likely served at wealthy banquets to showcase exotic ingredients from the Empire's frontiers.

name: Mesopotamian Lamb Stew
instructions: Toast barley in dry pot until fragrant, remove.
Brown lamb in animal fat until sealed on all sides.
Add onions and garlic, cook until softened.
Add cumin and coriander seeds, toast for 1 minute.
Return barley to pot with stock and beer.
Simmer for 1.5 hours until lamb is tender.
Add date syrup and dried mint in last 15 minutes.
Season with salt and serve in bowls.
history: This stew is reconstructed from cuneiform tablets from ancient Ur (circa 1750 BC) that describe temple kitchens. Barley was the staple grain of Mesopotamia, and lamb was the most common meat. The use of beer in cooking was typical - Mesopotamians drank beer daily through straws to avoid grain husks, and it was considered a divine gift from the gods.

name: Garum (Roman Fish Sauce)
instructions: Clean and gut small fish, leave whole.
Layer fish and salt in large earthenware pot.
Add herbs between layers for flavor.
Cover with vinegar and weigh down with stones.
Leave in sunny spot for 3 months, stirring monthly.
Strain liquid through fine cloth after fermentation.
Bottle the clear liquid - this is the garum.
Use as seasoning in place of salt or fish sauce.
history: Garum was the ketchup of the Roman world - used in nearly every savory dish. The best quality, 'garum sociorum,' came from Spain and cost a fortune. Roman factories from Portugal to the Black Sea produced millions of amphorae of this fish sauce. Pliny the Elder wrote about its medicinal properties, while the ruins of garum factories can still be visited in places like Baelo Claudia, Spain.

name: Tuh'u (Babylonian Beet Stew)
instructions: Heat oil, toast cumin and coriander seeds until fragrant.
Add onions and garlic, cook until softened.
Add beets and lentils, stir to coat with spices.
Pour in vegetable stock and bring to boil.
Reduce heat and simmer for 30 minutes.
Add date syrup and vinegar, cook 10 more minutes.
Season with salt to taste.
Garnish with fresh coriander and serve with flatbread.
history: Tuh'u comes from the Yale Babylonian Tablets (circa 1600 BC), making it one of the world's oldest recorded recipes. The tablets were discovered in ancient Mesopotamia and contain detailed culinary instructions. This beet stew was likely eaten by common people and may have been served in temple kitchens. The combination of beets and lentils shows the sophisticated vegetarian cuisine that developed in early agricultural societies.

name: Libum (Roman Sacrificial Cheese Bread)
instructions: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
Mix ricotta, spelt flour, egg, and salt into dough.
Knead gently until smooth but still soft.
Form into round loaf or individual cakes.
Line baking pan with bay leaves.
Place dough on bay leaves, creating indentations on top.
Bake for 25-30 minutes until golden.
Drizzle with honey while warm and serve.
history: Libum is described by Cato the Elder in 'De Agri Cultura' (160 BC) as a sacrificial cake offered to household gods. Roman families would bake these cheese breads for the Lares (household deities) during religious ceremonies. The bay leaves underneath weren't just for flavor - they created a sacred barrier between the mortal and divine realms. After the gods had their spiritual portion, the family would eat the physical libum.

name: Posca (Roman Legionary Vinegar Drink)
instructions: Mix water and red wine vinegar in pitcher.
Stir in honey until dissolved.
Add ground coriander and sea salt.
Let sit for 1 hour to allow flavors to meld.
Strain through cloth if desired.
Serve chilled or at room temperature.
Traditional soldier's drink for hydration.
Can be adjusted with more/less honey to taste.
history: Posca was the Gatorade of the Roman legions - a hydrating, slightly antiseptic drink that could be made with spoiled wine. Roman soldiers received posca as part of their daily rations, and it was mentioned in the New Testament as the drink offered to Jesus during his crucifixion. The vinegar's acidity killed bacteria in questionable water sources, making it safer to drink during military campaigns across the Empire.

name: Saffron Chicken (from Apicius)
instructions: Soak saffron in white wine for 15 minutes.
Brown chicken thighs in olive oil, remove from pan.
In same pan, add saffron-wine mixture and fish sauce.
Return chicken to pan, add dates and pine nuts.
Simmer covered for 25 minutes until chicken is tender.
Stir in cream and lovage in last 5 minutes.
Season with ground pepper (no salt needed due to garum).
Serve with spelt bread to soak up sauce.
history: This extravagant recipe from Apicius' cookbook showcases the incredible wealth of the Roman elite. Saffron was more expensive than gold by weight - it took 75,000 crocus flowers to produce one pound of saffron threads. Serving this dish demonstrated extreme wealth and sophistication. The recipe represents the height of Roman gourmet cuisine before the Empire's decline, when such luxuries became increasingly rare.
